items.content:
Frontend Focus

#â€‹496 â€” June 23, 2021 | Read on the web

A History of the Web â€” Matthew shares a look back at how the web has evolved into what we have today (going from the first HTML spec, right up to modern day React), along with thoughts as to why building web applications is so hard here inÂ 2021.

Matthew Gerstman

â–¶Â Â Top 10 Web Performance Pitfalls â€” Jake and Surma run through some of the top web performance issues theyâ€™ve seen recently across a bunch ofÂ sites.

Google Chrome Developers

Resolve Bugs and Manage Website Feedback Fast with BugHerd â€” Simple, effective QA and user acceptance testing. Pin bugs and feedback to your website. BugHerd captures all the technical information you need to replicate bugs and solve issues like a screenshot, and browser and OSÂ information.

BugHerd sponsor

Brave Unveils New 'Brave Search' Search Engine â€” Brave, perhaps better known for its privacy oriented browser, has unveiled Brave Search, a new privacy-oriented search engine of its own. Their biggest claim is itâ€™s built upon â€œa completely independent indexâ€ and thereâ€™s no tracking atÂ all.

Brave

A Complete Guide To Accessibility Tooling â€” A look into different kinds of tools to help you streamline your accessibility testingÂ process.

Nic Chan

  • Microsoft and Google have collaborated to bring support for dark mode form controls to Chromium.
  • AMP is no longer an eligibility factor when ranking in Google search.
  • This page from Marko Denic has a ton of handy HTML tips that are worth remembering.
  • Tim Berners-Lee has defended his decision to auction an NFT representing the 'source code' to the web.

Let's Learn About Aspect Ratios in CSS â€” Another from Ahmad, this time looking at how to use the native CSS aspect-ratioÂ property.

Watch Gavin Strangeâ€™s Series of Design Classes on Editor X

items.title: How best to serve images to high-density screens
items.content:
Frontend Focus

#â€‹495 â€” June 16, 2021 | Read on the web

When CSS Isnâ€™t Enough: JavaScript Requirements For Accessible Components â€” Stephanie Eckles looks at how components such as tooltips, modals, tabs, carousels, and dropdown menus often require more than just CSS (even when 'pure CSS' solutions are technically possible), especially to ensureÂ accessibility.

Smashing Magazine

Serving Sharp Images to High Density Screens â€” A majority of displays now have device to pixel ratios (DPR) higher than 1 (e.g. 'Retina' screens) â€”Â so whatâ€™s the best way to handle images in such high-density situations? Hereâ€™s a solid look at how to do just that (covering compression, delivery, etc.)

Jake Archibald

New & Updated Course: Complete Intro to React v6 with Brian Holt â€” Learn to build real-world applications using modern React. Much more than an intro, youâ€™ll start from the ground up, getting to using the latest features in React, including hooks, effects, context, and portals, plus piecing together tools from the entire ReactÂ ecosystem.

Frontend Masters sponsor

â–¶Â Â Design for Safari 15 â€” Apple has shared a half hour video, along with related resources, where Jen Simmons and Myles Maxfield covered all the upcoming Safari changes we saw in last week's WWDC keynote in more detail. Worth aÂ watch.

Apple

Introducing Aurora: A Collaboration Between Chrome and Open-Source Web Frameworks & Tools â€” A new initiative that aims to â€œdeliver the best user experience possible for production apps regardless of the browser youâ€™re rendering inâ€. Early days, but this post outlines the overallÂ goals.

Panicker, Osmani, Djirdeh (Google)

âš¡ï¸ Quick bits:

  • What if you could set whether you're ok with cookies or not at a browser level? This draft spec is proposing just that â€”Â could this make cookie banners obsolete?
  • Hmmm, the creator of the world wide web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee, is selling off the original code used to create the modern internet as an NFT. The auction takes place later this month.
  • Got Edge on your Mac? Well, you won't have to use Microsoft AutoUpdate to get new versions any more. Edge will update itself going forward.
  • Amazon is the latest to block Google's FLoC.
  • Here's a look at how the BBC approach development to ensure accessibility (and meet the corporation's a11y guidelines).
  • The performance.now() event is returning later this year for an actual in-person conference in Amsterdam. Details here.
  • WebExpo is also returning for an IRL event, this September in Prague.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Web Design Done Well: Making Use Of Audio â€” Audio on the web can often be a tricky thing to get right. Hereâ€™s a showcase of sites that get it right, nailing the userÂ experience.

Frederick O'Brien

Google Chrome Ends Its War On Address Bar URLsâ€”for Now, AtÂ Least â€” Yep, it appears as though Google is abandoning plans to display a â€˜simplifiedâ€™ domain in theÂ Omnibox.

Ron Amadeo

CSS System Colors â€” Itâ€™s not got universal support, but did you know you can use a range of keywords in CSS to set color values that are dependent on your system preferences. Jim digsÂ in.

Jim Nielsen

Progress Kendo UI for Angular sponsor

Stefan Judis

Thumbnail Hover Effect with SVG Filters â€” A simple thumbnail hover effect with a caption slide out animation and an SVG filter distortion on theÂ image.

Mary Lou

Microsoft Edge Team

Chris Coyier

MIT Energy Initiative

items.title: Safari Web Extensions go mobile
items.content:
Frontend Focus

#â€‹494 â€” June 9, 2021 | Read on the web

Safari Overhaul Includes Tab Groups and Web Extensions On Mobile â€” Apple unveiled its next version of Safari at WWDC earlier this week, featuring a new design, improvements to tab management, and the expansion of web extensions to both iPhone andÂ iPad. If you're feeling spicy and are running the beta you can find Apple's release notes for Safari 15 here.

Brittany A. Roston

Let Your Users Import Their Own Data, with Confidence â€” Integrate a production-ready data importer from Flatfile in minutes and let your users import their own data, securely, and with confidence. No Excel formatting, no custom import scripts, and no need to build vs.Â buy.

Flatfile Portal sponsor

How To Fix Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS) Issues â€” Googleâ€™s Core Web Vitals initiative has seen many sites get busy optimizing their Page Experience to maximize ranking factor. Here, Barry Pollard looks at the Cumulative Layout Shift metric thatâ€™s â€œcausing trouble to a lot of sitesâ€, and looks at ways of addressing any issues that come withÂ it.

Smashing Magazine

Looking at WCAG 2.5.5 for Better Target Sizes â€” Ever experienced the frustration of trying to tap a button on a mobile device only to have it do nothing because the target size is just not large enough? Todd dives into all things target size here, with advice on how to get the sizing justÂ right.

Todd Libby

Serverless Functions: The Secret to Ultra-Productive Front-End Teams? â€” The title screams evangelism but itâ€™s really genuine excitement at the opportunities serverless platforms open up for front-endÂ developers.

Jason Lengstorf

âš¡ï¸ Quick bits:

  • Yup, large chunks of the web went offline yesterday, following disruptions at Fastly. Will be interesting to see a full post-mortem on this one.
  • Version three of SF Symbols, Apple's icon library, is out now with over 600 new symbols to use.
  • Version 4.0 of the Vivaldi browser is out now.
  • Thanks to new JavaScript compiler Sparkplug, Chrome is now said to be up to 23% faster.
  • Yes, it's in beta, but a floating UI element in Safari for iOS 15 looks like it may cause a bit of frontend head-scratching. However, Apple's Jen Simmons reassures us it won't be an issue, and environment variables will help here.
  • At least a few of these 'HTTP status codes as dogs' will crack a smile.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

The Right Tag for The Job: Why You Should Use Semantic HTML â€” Hereâ€™s a decent guide to semantic HTML: what it is, why itâ€™s so important, and how to useÂ it.

Sophie Koonin

â–¶Â Â How to Find and Remove Dead CSS â€” Do you have old CSS styles hanging around in your project that youâ€™re afraid to remove because youâ€™re not sure if anything else is depending on them? This 25-minute video explores one way to get more confidence about which styles are actually unused and safe toÂ delete.

Justin Searls

VS Code Extensions for HTML â€” Letâ€™s look at some extensions for VS Code that make writing and editing HTML (and languages that are basically HTML with extra powers) better.

Chris Coyier

Can Firefoxâ€™s New Look Save The Web Browser? â€” We shared news last week of Firefox 89 â€”Â itâ€™s out now, complete with a fresh design. Hereâ€™s a quick interview with the team at Mozilla discussing the new look and its accessibilityÂ wins.

Daryl Baxter

New Mobile Chat Kit From Stream â€” Chat UI & SDKs for Figma, Sketch, Flutter, React Native, iOS, & Android. The UI includes flexible assets for creating customized, scalable, and beautiful in-app chatÂ experiences.

Stream sponsor

The Web We Choose to Build â€” Establishing principles for what you do can help frame things, and give focus. Hereâ€™s some thoughts on defining such principles for user-centred front-endÂ development.

Colin Oakley

Ancestors and Descendants â€” Some more worthwhile reflections from Eric on the evolution of CSS over the past 25 years, warts andÂ all:

â€œI know itâ€™s still fashionable to complain about how CSS is all janky and weird and unapproachable, but child, the wrinkles of today are a sunny park stroll compared to the jagged icebound cliff we faced at the dawn of CSSâ€

___
